title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Hook

In 1927, a psychologist noticed waiters could remember complex orders perfectly â€” until the bill was paid.
Then they forgot everything instantly.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is the Zeigarnik Effect.
The brain canâ€™t let go of incomplete tasks. It allocates background processing â€” like a browser tab you canâ€™t close.
Netflix forces a 3-second hook before â€œSkip Introâ€ appears. Marketers call this an open loop: start a pattern, donâ€™t close it.
The brain will stay to close the loop.

text:
You Just Saw It

The best presentations today didnâ€™t start with conclusions.
They started with a question. A tension. Something unresolved.
â€œThereâ€™s one fact that made me switch sides on this issue. Iâ€™ll get to it.â€
Did you stay to hear it? Thatâ€™s the loop.

Next Weekâ€™s Challenge

Open a loop in your first 10 seconds.
Donâ€™t close it until the end.

text:
The Hook

â€œYou have a tendency to be critical of yourself. You have a great need for others to like you. You have considerable unused capacity that you havenâ€™t turned to your advantage.â€
85% of people rate this as â€œhighly accurateâ€ for them.
Itâ€™s the same text for everyone.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is the Barnum Effect (Forer, 1949).
Statements that feel specific but apply to almost everyone create false intimacy. Horoscopes, psychics, personality tests â€” all exploit this.
The trick: moderate specificity + universal anxiety.
People remember the hits, forget the misses.

When a speaker said something like:
â€œSome of you are thinking, â€˜This doesnâ€™t affect me.â€™ But youâ€™re also wondering if youâ€™re doing enoughâ€¦â€
Did it feel personal? It wasnâ€™t. It was statistical.
But it worked.

The Hook

People holding a warm cup of coffee rated strangers as more trustworthy than those holding iced drinks.
They had no idea the cup mattered.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is Embodied Cognition (Williams & Bargh, 2008).
The body doesnâ€™t just receive information â€” it shapes judgment.

Physical warmth â†’ social warmth
Heaviness â†’ seriousness
Roughness â†’ difficulty

The brain takes sensory shortcuts constantly.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards

You Just Saw It

The arguments that landed today werenâ€™t abstract.
They made you feel something in your body.
Not â€œrising temperatures cause problems.â€
But: â€œYour grandmotherâ€™s lungs filling with smoke from a wildfire that didnâ€™t exist 20 years ago.â€

Next Weekâ€™s Challenge

Make your audience physically uncomfortable â€” on purpose.
One image. One sentence. Body-first.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Hook

Realtors show you a terrible, overpriced house first.
The second house â€” still overpriced â€” looks reasonable.
You donâ€™t evaluate houses. You evaluate differences from the anchor.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is Anchoring (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974).
The first number you hear distorts all subsequent judgment â€” even when itâ€™s obviously irrelevant.
In experiments, people estimated higher values after spinning a random wheel with higher numbers.
The brain cannot ignore the anchor.

You Just Saw It

When someone opened with an extreme number:
â€œAI could consume 30% of global electricity by 2040. Even the conservative estimate is 12%.â€
Now 12% sounds reasonable. But 12% is still catastrophic.
The anchor did its job.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
Next Weekâ€™s Challenge

Lead with the extreme. Then offer the â€œreasonableâ€ version.
Set the anchor before they do.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Hook

Which is more believable?
A: â€œThe project will take a few weeks.â€
B: â€œThe project will take 17 days.â€
B. Always B. Even if both are equally made up.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is the Specificity Heuristic.
The brain uses detail as a proxy for credibility. Specific = precise = probably measured = probably true.
Con artists and skilled liars know this: add irrelevant detail and people stop questioning.
â€œI was at the corner of 5th and Main at 3:47pmâ€ beats â€œI was downtown that afternoon.â€

You Just Saw It

Arguments that landed today had unnecessary precision:

Not â€œlots of energyâ€ â†’ â€œ415 TWhâ€
Not â€œmany peopleâ€ â†’ â€œ240 million peopleâ€
Not â€œrecentlyâ€ â†’ â€œMarch 2024â€

The detail signals: I didnâ€™t make this up.

Next Weekâ€™s Challenge

Replace every vague word with a specific number, date, or name.
Even if no one checks â€” theyâ€™ll believe you more.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Hook

The CIA developed a technique:
Before launching an operation, assume it failed catastrophically.
Then ask: â€œWhat went wrong?â€
Teams using pre-mortems catch 30% more risks.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is Prospective Hindsight (Mitchell et al., 1989).
Imagining failure as already happened unlocks different cognitive pathways than â€œwhat could go wrong?â€
The brain is better at explaining the past than predicting the future.
So you trick it: treat the future as past.

You Just Saw It

The teams that did well today anticipated the counterattack.
They didnâ€™t ask â€œwhat might they say?â€
They assumed: â€œWe lost. Why?â€
Then they fixed it before it happened.

Write three reasons why. Fix them.

text:
The Hook

â€œAre you going to let your family suffer, or are you going to act now?â€
The trick isnâ€™t the answer.
The trick is that both options accept your frame.

title: Weekly Strategy Cards
text:
The Science

This is the False Dilemma â€” or in sales, The Fork.
Present two choices that both serve your goal.
â€œDo you want the red one or the blue one?â€ (Not: â€œDo you want to buy a car?â€)
The brain loves binary choices. Multiple options = paralysis.
Two options = decision.

â€œWe can either regulate AI now, or let corporations decide for us.â€
Notice whatâ€™s missing?
â€œDo nothingâ€ wasnâ€™t an option. Because they didnâ€™t put it there.

Remove the third option before they think of it.

â€œ9 out of 10 people in your area pay their taxes on time.â€

Not moral appeal. Not threats. Just: youâ€™re the weird one if you donâ€™t.

text:
The Science

This is Social Proof + Normative Messaging.
But the key is: local and specific.

â€œMost peopleâ€ â†’ weak
â€œMost people in your buildingâ€ â†’ strong
â€œMost people in your building with kids your ageâ€ â†’ irresistible

The more similar the reference group, the more powerful the pull.

You Just Saw It

They said:
â€œEngineers at HKU are already shifting their research priorities.â€
A bandwagon that didnâ€™t exist until you named it.

Make it local. Make it specific. Make them the outlier if they disagree.

Every TV episode ends mid-scene.
Not at resolution â€” at maximum tension.
Breaking Bad ended seasons on unresolved gunshots, half-spoken sentences.

The Zeigarnik Effect again â€” now applied to structure.
But hereâ€™s the twist: anticipation is often more pleasurable than completion itself.
Dopamine spikes in anticipation, not reward.
Open strong. Return at the end â€” transformed.

This is Cognitive Dissonance (Festinger, 1957).

Cults donâ€™t brainwash. They get you to do things.

Behavior first. Belief follows.

Now youâ€™ve publicly identified. Your brain needs to reconcile that.

The space race was a 20th Century struggle between two nation-states, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US). The pursuit for both was the domination of space flight technologies. Pillar 1: Verifiability (Can It Be Fact-Checked?)
This is non-negotiable. Every fact, statistic, and story must have a source.







Grade
What It Looks Like




A
Every claim has a credible source (academic papers, major news outlets, official reports). Sources are recent and relevant. You could defend this in a court of fact-checkers.


B
Most claims sourced, sources are credible. One or two minor claims might lack citation but are easily verifiable.

D
Few or no sources. Claims are vague (â€œstudies showâ€¦â€) without specifics. Would fail a basic fact-check.


F
Invented facts, fabricated statistics, or made-up stories. This is academic dishonesty.

Weather Station Observations
Around the globe, millions of weather observations are recorded each day, by both human observers and automated instruments. In the United States, daily observations at stations that meet specified criteria, methodically collected by volunteer observers and automated weather stations, are used to document our weather and climate. One volunteer weather observer program in the United States is the Cooperative Observer Program (COOP).
This program, which includes more than 11,000 stations, is key to obtaining accurate observations across the country. Started in 1890, the COOP network now spans all corners of our nation: from mountaintops to meadows, urban to rural regions, and from seashores to suburbs.
Internationally this program also covers a great number of weather stations that are collectively recorded on NOAA.gov from the United States.
